title: How to find volume from density and mass - Quora

response.answer_text: d = m/V m = d×V V = m/d DENSITY Density is defined as mass per unit volume. d = m/V Example:A brick of salt measuring 10.0 cm x 10.0 cm x 2.00 cm has a mass of 433 g. What is its density? Step 1: Calculate the volumeV = lwh = 10.0 cm × 10.0 cm × 2.00 cm = 200cm³ Step 2: Calculate the density d = m/V = 433g200cm³= 2.16 g/cm³ MASS d = m/V We can rearrange this to get the expression for the mass. m = d×V Example:If 500 mL of a liquid has a density of 1.11 g/mL, what is its mass? m = d×V = 500 mL × 1.11g1mL = 555 g VOLUME d = m/V We can rearrange this to get the expression for the volume. V = m/d Example:What is the volume of a bar of gold that has a mass of 14.83 kg. The density of gold is 19.32 g/cm³. Step 1: Convert kilograms to grams. 14.83 kg × 1000g1kg = 14,830 g Step 2: Calculate the volume. V = m/d = 14 830 g × 1cm³19.32g = 767.6 cm³. Mass, density and volume triangle.

The other two answers, from J. Sullivan and M. Lopez, cover the question well in a formal sense. I would just add an answer oriented to the intuitive sense, hopefully to help comprehension. Say for example you were asked to find the volume of a water bucket and all you had available for measuring was a bathroom scale. So you weigh the bucket empty (1 kilo), fill it with water and weigh it again (11 kilos) and subtract to learn that the bucket held 10 kilos of water. You know that water has a density (weight per known standard volume) of 1 kilo per liter. So to learn the volume of the bucket you only need to divide the weight of the bucket's water by the density, 10 / 1 = 10 liters. Voila.
